awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Debugging by Design: Developing a Tool Set for Debugging with Electronic Textiles to Promote Computational and Engineering Thinking in High School
awd_abstract_narration:
Debugging is pervasive in both computing education and more generally in problem-solving across many disciplines. Project "Debugging by Design" focuses on the development of debugging for engineering electronic textiles as a central computational thinking practice by putting engineering into high school computer science (CS) classrooms. Unlike traditional approaches that teach debugging strategies, the goal of this project is to investigate a new instructional approach called "debugging by design" where the researchers turn the tables by having students and teachers themselves design debugging activities and materials supported by debugging tools. The hypothesis of the approach is that debugging by design will strengthen teachers' and students' learning of computational and engineering thinking while fostering a growth mindset around computational competencies. Electronic textile construction kits include sewable microcontrollers, sensors, and actuators combining computing, crafting, and engineering thus spanning both the physical and the computational. This particular hybrid medium is ideal for a study on the pedagogical value of debugging in fostering computational thinking in engineering. Bugs can exist in either or both of the media at the same time. Debugging such multi-faceted systems lends itself not only to the practice of computational thinking and programming as a technical skill, but it is also invaluable as a developmental skill leading to a growth mindset and the concept of "productive failure". The project is funded by the STEM+Computing program, which seeks to address emerging challenges in computational STEM areas through the applied integration of computational thinking and computing activities within disciplinary STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (preK-12). 

This project includes interconnected research and materials-design components. The instructional materials developed will be integrated into Exploring Computer Science (ECS) classrooms. The research questions that the project aims to answer include how debugging furthers computational thinking, how debugging encourages a growth mindset, how teachers embed project materials into ECS, and what teachers learn from designing debugging activities. Research will be carried out with ECS classrooms in the Los Angeles Unified School District and School District of Philadelphia. Researchers will work with 2 classrooms (35 students each) in each of the first two years and eight classrooms in the third year. Two "Debuggathons" (debugging design activities) will also be conducted in year 2, with both teachers and students jointly participating. The deliverables of the project include (a) debugging tool support that can help teachers and students debug the code and circuit designs in their advanced electronic textiles; (b) designs and implementations of instructional debugging activities that can be created and used by students and their teachers in Exploring Computer Science high school classrooms; and (c) student and teacher data and analysis that provide evidence on how doing and designing debugging activities can further students' computational thinking and foster a growth mindset.

por.por_cntn:
Debugging activities in physical computing provide a rich context to understand and foster cross-disciplinary problem solving, especially one that integrates learning of computing and engineering. This grant focused on developing tools and activities for learning and teaching of debugging that were accessible to teachers and students. Our work focused specifically on the domain of electronic textiles, but could be applied in other physical computing or screen-based coding domains. Electronic textiles are used in K-12 education with which students craft textile artifacts which include stitched circuits that connect sensors and actuators with conductive thread to a microcontroller that can be programmed. Learning to program and debug electronic textiles helps students better understand how many other everyday physical computing systems such as soap dispensers or traffic lights in their life operate. Learning debugging physical computing systems is a critical skill for students as CS education is becoming part of the K-12 curriculum because the programs they write and implement invariably will contain mistakes, or “bugs”, of various sorts ranging from simple typing mistakes to more complex program execution issues. In K-12 classrooms, debugging also presents particular challenges for teachers as students often need individual attention in identifying and then fixing bugs so that they can finish their programs. 


A major challenge and opportunity for students designing in physical computing domains has been identifying and fixing problems that emerge during open-ended design, in other words debugging or troubleshooting computational artifacts. Most previous efforts have taught students different strategies of debugging or presented them with problem sets for practice. In our grant we took a very different approach. We put the power of designing bugs into the hands of students in a small curricular unit called Debugging by Design. This 8-hour long extension activity was designed for the electronic textile unit which is part of Exploring Computer Science (ECS) curriculum. In this unit, students collaboratively discuss all the problems with coding and circuit designs they so far have experienced in making their electronic textiles, and then set out to develop a buggy e-textiles project for their classroom peers to fix. The unit underwent two years of iterative implementation and testing and then was converted for online implementation. In the online implementation students create detailed designs, code and instructions (all “buggy”) for other students to debug and create. (For more information on the research behind the design and classroom implementation of the Debugging by Design unit, please see http://exploringcs.org/e-textiles.) 


In our research we found that high school students who used these activities as part of their classroom activities developed growth mindset practices, debugging skills, deeper domain knowledge, and increased proclivity toward collaboration in problem solving (both in requesting and providing help with peers). A quasi experimental study design in the final year demonstrated that students in the experimental condition developed stronger growth mindset practices and fascination with computing than students who simply did another robust e-textiles project; this was especially true for students whose families did not attend college. We also performed microgenetic analysis of students’ debugging e-textiles in think aloud interviews, analyzed four case study groups and teachers’ instructional practices. Analysis of teacher practices also took place in fully online, virtual instruction when schools were closed because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Further, we developed and validated a survey on interest, values, fascination, personalization/creativity, and growth mindset with computer science that will be useful for other researchers.


In terms of intellectual merit, we (1) provided new insights into understanding students’ approaches to debugging (or troubleshooting) and types of bugs prominent in physical computing systems such as electronic textiles; (2) found that students who participated in debugging by design developed and engaged with practices that are associated with growth mindset; (3) documented that students whose parents had no college experience benefitted the most from participating in debugging by design activities (regardless of gender or ethnicity); (4) showed how teachers can use notional machines to explain how physical computing works; (5) illustrated how online PD and classroom teaching can be successfully revised for physical computing activities; and (6) developed and validated a survey on CS interest and growth mindset that could be useful in other research studies.


In terms of broadening participation, our findings suggest that debugging by design activities can support growing mindset practices of perseverance and support and learning of computer science amongst a large, diverse group of students regardless of gender or ethnicity. Further, engaging in online professional development with e-textiles can also support experienced CS teachers in going deeper in learning and pedagogy.  Our research directly reached over 400 high school students from underserved communities. Further, Debugging by Design is a concept that could be implemented in other computational domains besides e-textiles: in physical computing, screen-based code, and engineering domains.
